metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: Paleontological Resources of Monterey County, California, 2001

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: Geology resources and constraints Monterey County, California

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This point shapefile depicts paleontological resources within Monterey County, California. Fossils provide important evidence to help determine what happened in Earth history and when it happened. Today the animals and plants that live in the ocean are very different from those that live on land, and the animals and plants that live in one part of the ocean or on one part of the land are very different from those in other parts. Similarly, fossil animals and plants from different environments are different. It becomes a challenge to recognize rocks of the same age when one rock was deposited on land and another was deposited in the deep ocean. Scientists must study the fossils from a variety of environments to build a complete picture of the animals and plants that were living at a particular time in the past (Edwards and Pojeta, 1999).

purpose.gco:CharacterString: Because fossils are so useful to science, they need to be considered a resource and properly managed. The purpose of this database is to provide information on the type of fossil and the location so that these fossils may be preserved for science.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Rosenberg, Lewis, I. and Clark, Joseph C. (2001). Paleontological Resources of Monterey County, California, 2001. Monterey County (Calif.) Planning Department. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/xc583rw0668.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: This database is intended for regional planning purposes and not for site-specific evaluation. Information in this data set is preliminary in nature. This information is provided with understanding that it is not guaranteed to be correct or and conclusions drawn from such information, whether from individual use or aggregate use with other data, are the responsibility of the user.

hoursOfService.gco:CharacterString: Monday to Friday, 8 AM to 5 PM, Pacific Time

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: These data are believed to be logically consistent, although no tests were performed.

This database is based on an in-depth search of published and unpublished geologic literature, available oil well logs, interviews with USGS scientists that performed much of the source mapping, and the authors' personal knowledge and mapping. Therefore, the database is believed to be an exhaustive compilation and analysis of Monterey County paleontology. However, some oil company data is proprietary and unavailable, but is likely dupilicated elsewhere in the literature.
All attributes created during the creation process were verified by displaying the lines in both the database and the spatial coverage, but no formal tests were performed.

The paleontological localities are compiled from maps ranging from 1:24,000 to 1:62,500 scale. Using the "map resolution" concept outined by R.R. Wahl (USGS Open-File Report 99-386, p. 96: where (Map scale denominator) / 2/1000 = map scale, in meters), the estimated horizontal error ranges from 12 m (1:24,000 scale) to 31 m (1:65,000 scale).

description.gco:CharacterString: Rosenberg and Clark compiled a list of known fossil localities from 698 localities described in published and unpublished sources. To determine which localities were significant, Clark consulted with Earl E. Brabb, David L. Durham, Robert J. McLaughlin, and Charles L. Powell, II, all of or formerly of the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park and reviewed the available published and unpublished literature. The latter consisted mainly of graduate student theses at U.C. Berkeley and at Stanford University. Clark reviewed the list and considered that 12 of these localities were of outstanding stratigraphic or historic significance. Each described locality has been plotted as accurately as possible on 7 ½-minute quadrangles and incorporated into a GIS database.

hoursOfService.gco:CharacterString: Monday to Friday, 8 AM to 5 PM, Pacific Time

description.gco:CharacterString: Ichnofossil assemblage at Weston Beach, Point Lobos contains an unique well preserved and diverse trace-fossil assemblage that represents a mixture of "shallow-water" and "deep-water" types.

title.gco:CharacterString: Miocene stratigraphy of California

description.gco:CharacterString: publication date
Well-exposed and well-preserved bioherm of the colonial barnacle, Balanus gregarious (Conrad), is one of only two such known fossil localities in the Tertiary of California (USGS loc. 3586).

title.gco:CharacterString: Cretaceous beds at Slate's Hot Springs, California

name.gco:CharacterString: Bulletin of the Department of Geological Sciences

description.gco:CharacterString: publication date

Monterey Formation along Reliz Creek yields benthic and planktic foraminifers and calcareous nannofossils that enable correlation of the upper part of the Relizian Stage in its type area with the Burdigalian Stage of Europe (ca. 18.0 to 17.0 Ma).

title.gco:CharacterString: Microfossils from the type Relizian and Luisian stages of California, in Garrison, R.E., and Douglas, R.G., eds., The Monterey Formation and related siliceous rocks of California

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Society of Economic Paleontologists and Mineralogists, Pacific Section

description.gco:CharacterString: publication date

Unusually well-preserved megainvertebrate fauna includes pectinids, echinoids, muricid gastropods, and barnacles (USGS loc. M903). Extensive, well-documented megainvertebrate fauna includes echinoids, gastropods, pelecypods, and barnacles (USGS loc. M1935).
